description.narrative:
FONERWA has applied to Sida for funding of 39 million SEK to build institutional capacity to deliver on its manadates under the "Institutional Support to FONERWA project" in Rwanda during the period November 2018 to June 2021. In addition to this, 1 million SEK will be allocated for studies and analyses procured directly by the Embassy, which includes a review of FONERWA's internal management and control system.
The intervention aims at an overall level at supporting FONERWA, Rwanda's national climate and environment fund, to contribute to that Rwanda's economic growth is environentally sustainable, low carbon and climate resilient and contributes to wealth creation and poverty reduction; that adaptive capacity of communities is increased; and vulnerability to climate change reduced.
Sweden will contribute to the following expected outcomes of the intervention: Sustainable and equitable finance supports national programmes and private initiatives to address climate and environment priorities; Skills acquired by National stakeholders and CSO’s in particular applied in the design of project proposals; Bankable projects developed and approved for funding by FONERWA board; and Completed projects, successfully implemented and lessons learned shared.
The above will be achieved by the following outputs: 1) Awareness raised on the relationships between climate, environment and economic development for potential implementers 2) The Fund is sustainably, cost effectively and transparently managed. 3) Environment and climate change issues mainstreamed into policies, programmes, plans budgets and activities for public and non-public agencies 4) Capacity building (CB) modules developed and adopted by National CSO’s 5) National CSO’s trained by International NGO’s to design and develop proposals targeting FONERWA 6) Increased knowledge of National CSO’s on climate change and environmental challenges. 7) Increased participation of NGOs in addressing climate and environment priorities at the National level. 8) Technical knowledge and skills transferred to National CSO’s by International NGO’s during project implementation. (FONERWA Theory of change, submitted 2 November 2018)
The intervention's total budget is presently 417 milion SEK (appr. 47,1 million USD), out of which the Government of Rwanda provides appr. 8.9 million SEK (1 million USD), DFID 47 million SEK (5,3 million USD), KfW 36 million SEK (4,1 million USD) and Green Climate Fund (GCF) 285 million SEK (32,2 million USD). Approximately 365 million SEK (41,2 million USD) will be forwarded to third party for project implmentations. The remaining part of the budget will be used for technical assistance and FONERWA's operations. The total value of the fund and distribution over the years to come is difficult to estimate since it concerns a fund. The main part of the Swedish funding, appr. 80%, will be forwarded to third party organisations for project implementation. The rest will be used for technical assistance and FONERWA's operational costs. The technical assistach to which Sweden will contribute will focus on CSO:s in the environment sector, capacity building of FONERWA and improved gender integration.

FONERWA, Rwandas nationella klimat- och miljöfond, har hos Sida ansökt om finansiering om 39 miljoner kronor för institutionellt stöd av FONERWA under perioden november 2018 till juni 2021. I tillägg till denna summa har 1 miljon kronor reserverats för studier och analyser att upphandlas direkt av ambassaden, däribland en översyn av FONERWA:s system för intern styrning och kontroll.
Insatsen syftar på en övergripande nivå till att stödja FONERWA i deras uppdrag att bidra till att: Rwandas ekonomiska tillväxt är miljömässigt hållbar, har låga koldioxidutsläpp och har motståndskraft mot klimatförändringar samt bidrar till att skapa välstånd och fattigdomsminskning; att den adaptiva kapaciteten i samhället ökar; och att sårbarheten för klimatförändringar minskar.
Sverige kommer att bidra till följande insatsmål: Uthållig och rättvis finansiering av nationella program och privata initiativ för att adressera miljö- och klimatprioriteringar; Att färdigheter som förvärvats av nationella aktörer och civilsamhällesorganisationer (CSOs) i synnerhet används vid utformningen av projektförslag; Att finansieringsbara projektförslag har utvecklats och godkänts för finansiering av FONERWA:s styrelse samt; Att projekten framgångsrikt har genomförts och erfarenheter delats.
Följande resultat förväntas leda till att ovanstående mål uppfylls: 1) Ökad medvetenhet om förhållandet mellan klimat, miljö och ekonomisk utveckling bland möjliga aktörer som genomför projekt 2) Fonden hanteras på ett hållbart, kostnadseffektivt och transparent sätt 3) Miljö- och klimatfrågor integreras i policyer, program, budgetar, planer och aktiviteter inom offentlig sector och andra organisationer 4) Modeller för kapacitetsuppbyggnad har utvecklats och antagits av nationella civilsamhällesorganisationer (CSO:er) 5) Nationella CSO:er har utbildats av internationella CSO:er i att utforma och utveckla projektförslag riktade till FONERWA 6) Ökad kunskap inom nationella CSO:er om klimatförändringar och miljöutmaningar. 7) Ökat deltagande av CSO:er för att hantera klimat- och miljöprioriteringar på nationell nivå. 8) Tekniska kunskaper och färdigheter har under porjektperioden överförts från internationella till nationella CSO:er. (Enligt FONERWA:s förändringsteori, enligt mail till ambassaden 2 november 2018)
Insatsens totala budget uppgår för närvarande till 417 miljoner kr (ca 47,1 MUSD) till vilken Rwanda bidrar med ca 8,9 miljoner kr (1 MUSD), DFID 47 miljoner kr (5,3 MUSD), KfW 36 miljoner kr (4,1 MUSD) och Gröna Klimatfonden (GCf) 285 miljoner kr (32.2 MUSD). Ca 365 miljoner kr (41,2 MUSD) kommer att vidareförmedlas till organisationer som genomför olika projekt. Resten av budgeten kommer att användas för konsultstöd och FONERWA:s löpande kostnader. Fondens sammantagna värde och fördelning över tid är svår att förutspå då det rör sig om fond. Merparten av den svenska finansieringen, ca 80%, kommer att vidareförmedlas till tredje part som genomför fondens projekt. Resten av budgeten kommer att användas för konsultstöd och FONERWA:s löpande kostnader. Det konsultstöd till vilket Sida har för avsikt att bidra kommer att fokusera på att stärka CSO:er inom miljösektorn, kapacitetsutveckling av FONERWA samt till förbättrad jämställdhetsintegrering .

The intended impact of supporting FONERWA is that Rwanda's economic growth becomes environmentally sustainable, low carbon and climate resilient. The following are foreseen results according to FONERWA's results framework: - Conservation and management of natural resources strengthened and sustained. - Renewable energy and other environmentally sustainable low carbon and climate resilient practices and approaches adopted developed and/or improved. - Environment and climate change issues, mainstreamed into policies, programmes, plans and budgets and activities for public and non-public agencies. - The Fund is sustainably, cost effectively and transparently managed This will be done mainly through the delivery of high quality climate and environment projects and programmes as well as through improved institutional capacity for mainstreaming climate change into existing and future progamming. In addition to the results framework FONERWA has submitted a Theory of Change (ToC) for Sida's contribution. The expected impact is similar for the two documents but differs when it comes to outcomes and outputs. The expected outcome of the intervention is that: Sustainable and equitable finance supports national programmes and private initiatives to address climate and environment priorities; Skills acquired by National stakeholders and CSO’s in particular applied in the design of project proposals; Bankable projects developed and approved for funding by FONERWA board; and Completed projects, successfully implemented and lessons learned shared. The above will be achieved by the following outputs: 1) Awareness raised on the relationships between climate, environment and economic development for potential implementers 2) The Fund is sustainably, cost effectively and transparently managed. 3) Environment and climate change issues mainstreamed into policies, programmes, plans budgets and activities for public and non-public agencies 4) Capacity building (CB) modules developed and adopted by National CSO’s 5) National CSO’s trained by International NGO’s to design and develop proposals targeting FONERWA 6) Increased knowledge of National CSO’s on climate change and environmental challenges. 7) Increased participation of NGOs in addressing climate and environment priorities at the National level. 8) Technical knowledge and skills transferred to National CSO’s by International NGO’s during project implementation. (FONERWA Theory of change, submitted 2 November 2018)

description.narrative: General achievments: Since the start, ten rounds of call for proposals have been completed with 37 projects being funded, according to an external programme completion review commissioned by FCDO in Oct 2020. Of these, 28 projects have been completed contributing funding worth RWF 25.9bn (£20.5m). Nine further projects are still under implementation, with total funds committed worth RWF 12bn (£9.4m). Most grant funds mobilised have gone to central Government (54%) and district-led projects (37%), with 4% of total funds supporting private sector (7 firms to date), and the remaining (5%) to NGOs. As of October 2020, the Fund has cumulatively mobilised $188 million,which makes FONERWA one of the largest government-run, demand-based climate funds in Africa. FONERWA also supported the Rwanda Ministry of Environment to be the first Ministry in Africa to get national entity accreditation with the Green Climate Fund (GCF); and in 2018, the Fund won the UN Global Climate Action Award (Financing for Climate Friendly Investment category). The Fund continues to innovate and be invited to share its learning at many high-level international events. In recent years, the Fund has been able to mobilise resources from an increasing range of donors, who contributed through either seed capitalisation or programmatic funding/co-financing. In 2019-2020 FONERWA signed three more partnership agreements, reaching 21 in total. 22 proposals have been submitted to partners for funding. Donors include, according to size: FCDO (phasing out), Green Climate Fund, KFW, Adaptation Fund, UNDP, LDCF/AfDB, GoR and domestic resources (4.3%), Nordic Development Fund, World Bank, Sida (2.3%), Global Green Growth Institute, Rwanda Development Bank, CDKN, Global Housing Solutions (GHS). Main results achieved to date include: 21,914 ha of land secured against erosion 43,154 ha of forest and agro-forset cover 27,984 ha of protected watershed. 73,251 number of households with access to clean energy. 93,604 tonnes of CO2 emissions avoided. 111,323 people supported to cope with effects of climate change. 14 programmes of action in Rwanda’s Green Growth and Climate Resilience Strategy supported. 145,256 green jobs created as a result of the Fund, of which 60% include women. According to FCDO's completion review, the results above are well beyond those originally planned for. Out of five outputs, only one (output 1 - Conservation and management of natural resources strengthened and sustained) very moderately did not meet expectations, while one (output 4 - Resource mobilization and partnership strategy effectively implemented) moderately exceeded expectations. The remaining three outputs met or exceeded expectations. Sida-funded projects Nov 2018 - Dec 2020: Sida's funding since Nov 2018 have been going to the implementation of four projects in the following GoR priority sectors: climate-smart agriculture, biomass replacement and sustainable transport. Two of the projects have been completed while two other are still ongoing. According to FONERWA's semi-annual report July - Dec 2020 the following outcomes have been achieved: 1. Greening Girinka project (still ongoing): The project is supporting 480 households to pilot climate-smart technologies and techniques for improved livestock development and soil fertility of smallholder crop-livestock systems. It will produce scientific reports from research to demonstrate practices that address the growing environmental degradation caused by livestock development and the use of inorganic fertilisers in Rwanda. 96 households have been selected to take part in trials to monitor the feed and weight gain of animals to identify the most productive animals, providing evidence for future breeding policies and programmes. 480 households were also trained on climate-smart vegetable production techniques and fodder planting, maintenance and conservation. The households were given inputs to farm to improve the food security. Farmers also continued to participate in the research and have selected suitable fodders to according to criteria set by themselves including high biomass, green leaves, vigor, drought tolerance, disease resistance, capacity of seed production, and re-growth capacity. A new activity to carry out capacity assessment of extension services was started, with the purpose to develop a capacity development plan to enhance the capacity of extension services to utilize climate smart technologies and techniques. In addition, the tree nursery beds were maintained and drought tolerant indigenous trees cuttings planted and maintained. 2. Supporting the Integration of Village Greening Program (ongoing) The project is implemented by Rwanda Housing Authority (RHA). It intends to reduce vulnerability of 456 households by construct rainwater harvesting tanks for drinking water and green houses for farming, in Ntebe Village in Muhazii Sector, Rwempasha Village in Rwempasha Sector, and Umunini Village in Mahama Sector. 80 households have been trained in smart greenhouse farming, and learnt about best practices to support the the cooperatives and improve the livelihoods of the beneficiaries, related to the greenhouses to be installed. The project has however experienced challenges and delays. According to FONERWA this is mainly due to the fact the tender did not yield any successful bidder for the construction of 400 cubic metres of underground rain water harvesting system. There was also weak ownership due to lack of dedicated project staff as RHA used existing employees to implement the project, who had little time to spend on the same, over and above their normal work tasks. The delays and lack of progress have lead to a decision by FONERWA to terminate the contract with Rwanda Housing Authority. FONERWA has made a request to Sida to continue with the project but with a different agreement partner, i.e. the district authority. This because there are expectations by the communties and the project had already delivered some outputs like trainings and awarness raising. Sida has approved of this request after close dialoge with FONERWA to ensure that sufficient monitoring and follow up is in place to ensure efficient implementation going forward. 3. Transforming Rwanda National Police into an efficient and low-carbon energy consumption institution project (ended): This project intended to transform the police force into an efficient and low-carbon institution, to reduce the GHG emissions from its cooking operations, and improve the health of personnel. All the activities have been completed; 72 cooking stoves have been transformed from wood fuel to gas. Remaining is to provide advanced training to the police force personnel to maintain the cooking gas infrastructure. 1 164 personnel were removed from indoor pollution as a result of installing the new system for cooking. The personnel will avoid the risk of respiratory diseases associated with indoor smoke from cooking with wood fuel. The project also significantly contributed to avoiding Co2 emissions. 4. Electric Motors project (ended): Ampersand has implemented the e-moto project with the objective to test, demonstrate and improve an electric motorcycle taxi (e-moto) and grid-powered battery charging system in Rwanda. This was a pilot project which has completed all planned activities. According to FONERWA, the project has demonstrated that the electric motorcycles are a cheaper, cleaner and higher performing alternative to the petrol motos currently used by tens of thousands of drivers in Rwanda. The following targets were achived: • 25 electric motos have been registered in Rwanda and 20 e-moto taxis are on the road • 2 charging stations were established to facilitate the drivers to change batteries.• 4 applications for battery drop off, battery swapping, battery pickup and cash collection were synchronized with the google document for tracking. The project has also provided key information and data that informed the e-mobility policy in Rwanda. It provided inputs on policy recommendations, including regulatory and the impact of calculations for fiscal incentives including tax and duty exemptions, and different electricity tariffs. A proposal for funding and scaling up has been submitted to the NAMA Facility (supported by Germany, EU Commission, UK) in the beginning of 2021. Sida support to institutional strenthening of FONERWA: A portion of Sida's support is earmarked for institutional support to FONERWA in the areas of coaching and mentoring CSOs, effective methods of gender inclusion, integration of environment and social concerns, as well as resource mobilization. A team of consultants were recruited to support FONERWA and who started working in Jan 2020. The TA contract is a joint collaboration between Sida, KfW (owns the contract) and FCDO (who has phased out). The contract is over two years and ends Dec 2021. The TA has delivered the following so far: 1 - Coaching and Mentoring Civil Society Organizations (CSOs) on the relationship between climate change, environment and economic development and development of project proposals targeting FONERWA. A grant agreement/management guidelines/templates for CSOs were completed and shared with the grant awardees and a draft CSO capacity building plan was completed. 2 - Building FONERWA’s institutional capacity in effective methods of gender inclusion in program design and implementation. A gender mainstreaming strategy, one year action plan, and handbook have been completed, as well as a roll-out plan. 3 - Support for the development and roll-out out of an Environmental and Social Management Framework (ESMF). All volumes (Vol 1, 2, 3 & 4) have been completed. 4 - Support in the development and the roll-out of a Resource Mobilization Strategy were completed as well as two trainings, to unlock additional funding sources and capacity building for staff to be effective in mobilizing a wide range of resources. 5 - General governance and management support in the fields of institutional and human resource development, monitoring and evaluation, financial project management and reporting, and ICT. A Development Partners' Forum has been established, a job analysis and training needs assessment done, M&E manual developed, the revision of the Strategic Plan 2019-2024 is under preparation, the ICT strategy is finalized and the Communication Strategy is under preparation.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
